scenes.title: Adder's Tongue Gate
scenes.text: The iron gate groaned. A sound like grinding bone. Elara stood before it. The ache in her marrow pulled her here. An unnatural, pale light spilled from within the cemetery, casting long, distorted shadows. A whisper, thin as smoke, coiled in her ear. *Home.*

scenes.title: The Stone Path
scenes.text: Gravel crunched. The main path was unnaturally clean. Headstones leaned like bad teeth on either side. A thick, grey smoke drifted from deeper in the grounds. It swirled without wind. It smelled of dust and something metallic. The ache in her bones intensified.

scenes.title: The Crumbling Wall
scenes.text: The stone was cold and slick with moss. Elara pulled herself over the wall, dropping into a patch of dead leaves. The sound was a gunshot in the silence. She froze. Listened. Only the hum of that strange, sterile light. This side of the cemetery was wild, forgotten.

scenes.title: The Ancestral Crypt
scenes.text: There it was. A small stone building, her family name carved above the door. The source of the deep, resonant pain in her skeleton. The air was colder here. The smoke seemed to leak from the cracks around the heavy stone door. A faint scratching came from within.

scenes.title: The Empty Earth
scenes.text: The smoke rose from a pit. An open grave, clawed from the earth. More graves lay empty around it. Piles of dirt and splintered wood. Then, movement in the pit. A bone, pale white, lifted from the soil. Then another. They clicked together. A sound like knitting needles. Something was being assembled.

scenes.title: Blind Panic
scenes.text: She ran. Didn't look back. The clicking, scraping sound followed. It was fast. Faster than it should be. Branches tore at her clothes. She stumbled through a thicket of thorns and saw a small, dilapidated building ahead. A groundskeeper's shed.

scenes.title: Bone-Lattice
scenes.text: Elara grabbed a heavy iron fence post. The thing pulled itself from the grave. A lattice of human bones—arms and ribs and leg bones—all woven together. It scuttled on mismatched limbs. She swung. The iron connected with a sickening crack. It shrieked, a sound of scraping stone, and lunged. She brought the post down again and again. Bone shards flew like shrapnel. A piece of jawbone, half an old locket still caught in the teeth, clattered to the ground.

scenes.title: The Groundskeeper's Shed
scenes.text: The door slammed shut. The air smelled of rust and rot. On a small desk, a leather-bound journal lay open. The writing was frantic. It spoke of a 'Knitter of Marrow', a presence that unearths the dead to build a new body. It mentioned a ritual of severance, needing an object of 'ancestral silver' and a focus at the 'heart of the grounds'. The clicking and scraping grew louder just outside the door.

scenes.title: Inside the Crypt
scenes.text: The stone door ground open. Inside, stone shelves held the coffins of her line. The ache in her bones was a deafening roar here. A small stone altar stood at the back, bare except for a shallow depression in its center. The whispers were a chorus now. *Join us. Become whole.*

scenes.title: The Other Tombs
scenes.text: She darted between the mausoleums. The door to one was ajar. Peeking inside, she saw it. Dozens of skeletal forms, twitching. Ribcages were being pried apart, spines lengthened, limbs attached to other limbs. The smoke was thick here, and it began to cling to her, heavy and cold. It seeped into her skin. Her bones began to pull, to shift. She was part of the material now.

scenes.title: The Blood Resonance
scenes.text: Her hand touched the cold stone. A shock, not of electricity, but of knowledge. A vision of a being made of smoke and will, the Knitter. It had waited. It needed a final piece. A living vessel from the line that first bound it here. Her blood. Her bones. The altar flared with light. The ache became a feeling of rightness. Of completion. Her skin peeled back from her hands, revealing bone shining with pale light.

scenes.title: The Silver Locket
scenes.text: The wood of the oldest coffin was rotten. It splintered easily. Inside, only dust and scraps of cloth. The skeleton was gone. All that remained was a small, tarnished silver locket on a chain. It was cold to the touch, and the whispers in her head recoiled from it. *Ancestral silver.*

scenes.title: The Gatekeeper
scenes.text: She ran. The gate was in sight. But it was blocked. A mountain of bone and tissue and grave soil was pulling itself together. Dozens of bodies, dozens of skeletons, all knit into one towering, multi-limbed horror. The Marrow-Knit. It turned its many heads toward her, and every silent mouth opened at once.

scenes.title: The Ruined Chapel
scenes.text: The chapel had no roof. It was open to the unnaturally bright sky. In the center, where the altar should be, was a churning vortex of smoke and bone. The Marrow-Knit was forming here, drawing all the cemetery's dead into its mass. A great, still-forming leg of fused femurs and tibias slammed down near her. This was the heart of the grounds.

scenes.title: The Severance
scenes.text: She stood before the forming beast, holding the silver locket. She remembered the words from the journal. A quiet chant, not of power, but of refusal. Of closing a door. The locket began to glow, a clean, cold light. The Marrow-Knit paused its formation. It sensed her. It sensed the silver. It let out a shriek of a thousand voices, a sound of pure rage, and a limb made of tombstone and spine lashed out.

scenes.title: Unknitted
scenes.text: The limb struck the ground where she had been a second before, but the chant was complete. The locket flared, a silent explosion of silver light. The Marrow-Knit convulsed. The smoke binding it together hissed and evaporated. Bones, hundreds of them, clattered to the floor, inert. The whispers stopped. The unnatural light faded, replaced by the simple grey of dawn. The ache in her bones was gone.

scenes.title: The Final Thread
scenes.text: She dodged, but the force of the blow threw her to the ground. The locket flew from her hand. The chant died in her throat. The Marrow-Knit's form solidified. It loomed over her, a god of stolen parts. A tendril of smoke, now as solid as sinew, wrapped around her ankle. It pulled her in. She felt her own bones crack and yearn to join the whole. The last thing she saw was her own hand merging with the creature's flesh.

scenes.title: Cornered
scenes.text: She kept running. Deeper into the cemetery. But there was no escape. She ran into a dead end, a high wall of mausoleums. The clicking and scraping came from all sides. Three of the Bone-Lattices emerged from the shadows. They circled her. Their movements were jerky, unnatural. The whispers returned, a dizzying cacophony inside her skull. There was nowhere to go. Only the clicking. The clicking and the laughing whispers.
